awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FET: Medium: Biological production and enzymatic processing for defect-free, scalable nucleic-acid circuits
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of “chemical central processing units” will make possible computation in bio-chemical contexts that can sense from the environment, process information, and actuate a physical response. Necessary to this goal are fast, robust and composable molecular components that can implement logic behavior with physical molecules, much like electronic components have been successfully used to process information. One attractive candidate is DNA Strand Displacement (DSD) circuits. Despite the promise of DSD circuits, there are a number of perceived barriers to their widespread adoption as a technology: (i) DSD circuits are slow & error-prone, (ii) preparation of DSD circuit components is difficult and does not easily scale, (iii) DSD circuit components, even when purified, contain defects, and (iv) measuring & controlling the concentration of DSD circuit components is problematic. Recent breakthroughs in “leakless” DSD systems have seen the first barrier fall. The project includes plans for training students at all level.

The investigators are addressing the three remaining barriers to widespread adoption of DSD circuit technology. The team of researchers is combining robust nucleic-acid circuit architectures, methods of producing long, high-fidelity single-stranded DNA, additional enzymatic methods, and new experimental protocols in order to simultaneously address all four of the identified barriers. The project intends to demonstrate that biologically amplified, enzymatically prepared DSD components lead to superior nucleic-acid logic circuits leading to entirely new applications of this technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The larger goal of this collaborative project has been to engineer biomolecular circuits that can operate in a more reliable manner than has been achieved to date. Mastery over such behavior could form the foundation of molecular robotics, where programmed collections of molecules could sense features of the environment, perform computations based on these sensed inputs, and then actuate effects on th environment as a response.

 

Our architecture of choice is known as DNA Strand Displacement (DSD) Circuits. These are attractive due to the ease of handling of DNA as a material, and the robustness of methods for programming orthogonal interactions between various components in solution. Our collaborator, Chris Thachuk at University of Washington, has been one of the pioneers of “leakless” DSD systems that greatly reduce the errors that have been prevalent for previous systems. Nevertheless, because these systems are assembled from chemically synthesized DNA components bearing a significant percentage of chemical defects, therefore difficulties remain in efforts to produce the elements at scale and keeping error rates at even lower levels.

 

In this work, we sought to address these issues by producing the DNA components either enzymatically in vitro, or else biologically in bacteria. This enables generation of long DNA strands that should contain orders of magnitude fewer defects than those produced by chemical synthesis. The steps involved in biological production of the DNA circuit components are four-fold: (1) amplify large amounts of defect-free top and bottom strands, each encoding a desired series of components separated by spacers, in the genomes of viruses that infect bacteria (both of which are harmless to people); (2) hybridize the top and bottom strands together, and then use protein-based enzymes to cleave out spacers to liberate the functional circuit components, which resemble double-stranded DNA but also contain features such as single-stranded DNA bulges and sticky ends; (3) (iv)     measure the concentration of the standard using a calibrated fluorescent re- porter for facile quantitation of component set concentration.

 

In this project, we focused on production of programmed inserts that are about 1500 units long. Through optimization of parameters of the procedure, such as the concentration of bacteria in the step immediately prior to infection with the virus, the amount of virus to add, the duration of the growth post-infection, and the level of aeration of the bacterial culture, we were able to increase out yield about ten-fold compared to our initial trials. We next would like to test a mutation recently reported in the literature that could lead to even greater yields. Optimizing the yields of these biochemical circuit components will prove an important enabler of progress in building robust, low-error DSD circuits.
